 ----- Original Message -----  "From: Dr John P Lissenden 
  I was very =
interested by the article that you posted on namban tetsu,  but am a little=
 unhappy about the implied supposition that cannon from the 'De Liefde' wer=
e the original source of this metal. I had believed that bronze - a mixture=
 of 90% copper and 10% tin - was the preferred metal used for the casting o=
f cannon. Although cast-iron cannon became available ca 1550, these were mu=
ch more difficult to cast, and bronze remained the metal of choice until th=
e mid to late C17. Since the 'De Liefde' arrived in Kyushu in 1600, is it n=
ot highly likely that its cannon were of bronze rather than of iron? Is the=
re an expert on cannon out there somewhere who can clarify this point for m=
e? Regards, John L."
 
The cannon on the 'De Liefde' were indeed made out o=
f bronze. This was verfied by a cargo manifest prepared by a Jesuit that wa=
s sent on board to inspect the ship.
